articles.headline: Elon Musk to Workers: Spend 40 Hours in the Office, or Else
articles.snippet: In emails to workers at SpaceX and Tesla, Mr. Musk said they were required to spend a minimum of 40 hours a week in the office.
articles.abstract: In emails to workers at SpaceX and Tesla, Mr. Musk said they were required to spend a minimum of 40 hours a week in the office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is demanding that his workers return to the office.

articles.headline: The Next Battleground for Gig Worker Labor Laws: Massachusetts
articles.snippet: Uber and Lyft are pushing a ballot measure that would bar their drivers from full employment status, but a court could throw it out.
articles.abstract: Uber and Lyft are pushing a ballot measure that would bar their drivers from full employment status, but a court could throw it out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two years after a fierce election fight in California, gig companies like Uber and Lyft are again colliding with labor groups, politicians and the courts over a ballot measure in Massachusetts that would preserve the independent status of drivers for the companies.

articles.headline: Putin’s Threats Highlight the Dangers of a New, Riskier Nuclear Era
articles.snippet: After generations of stability in nuclear arms control, a warning to Russia from President Biden shows how old norms are eroding.
articles.abstract: After generations of stability in nuclear arms control, a warning to Russia from President Biden shows how old norms are eroding.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The old nuclear order, rooted in the Cold War’s unthinkable outcomes, was fraying before Russia invaded Ukraine. Now, it is giving way to a looming era of disorder unlike any since the beginning of the atomic age.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: A whistle, then a deadly barrage. Ukraine’s soldiers are under relentless fire.
articles.snippet: The attention on Russia’s battle casualties has obscured the heavy losses of Ukraine’s fighters in Donbas — often ill-trained volunteers.
articles.abstract: The attention on Russia’s battle casualties has obscured the heavy losses of Ukraine’s fighters in Donbas — often ill-trained volunteers.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — It all starts with a whistle, said Vladislav Goncharenko, a Ukrainian army sergeant, describing the relentless Russian shelling.

articles.headline: Europe’s Russian Oil Ban Could Overhaul Global Energy Market
articles.snippet: The effort could hurt Russia but could also help drive up already high oil prices, hurting the global economy and enriching energy companies.
articles.abstract: The effort could hurt Russia but could also help drive up already high oil prices, hurting the global economy and enriching energy companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The European Union’s embargo on most Russian oil imports could deliver a fresh jolt to the world economy, propelling a realignment of global energy trading that leaves Russia economically weaker, gives China and India bargaining power and enriches producers like Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: Sheryl Sandberg Is Stepping Down From Meta
articles.snippet: The longtime chief operating officer of Facebook’s parent company, Ms. Sandberg has had a lower profile during Mark Zuckerberg’s pursuit of the so-called metaverse.
articles.abstract: The longtime chief operating officer of Facebook’s parent company, Ms. Sandberg has had a lower profile during Mark Zuckerberg’s pursuit of the so-called metaverse.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, recruited a Google executive named Sheryl Sandberg to his social network in 2008, he said he had hired her because “she has just about the most relevant industry experience for Facebook, especially since we need to scale our operations and scale them globally.”
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: The Middlemen at the Heart of an Oligarch-Industrial Complex
articles.snippet: They oversee the flow of billions of dollars from Putin-connected Russians to companies involved in superyachts and villas. They’ve drawn the attention of a U.S. task force.
articles.abstract: They oversee the flow of billions of dollars from Putin-connected Russians to companies involved in superyachts and villas. They’ve drawn the attention of a U.S. task force.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, as Russian troops poured into Ukraine on Day 1 of the invasion, an employee of a yacht management company sent an email to the captain of the Amadea, a $325 million superyacht: “Importance: High.”
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe, Gaia Pianigiani and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A Disturbing New Pattern in Mass Shootings: Young Assailants
articles.snippet: Six of the nine deadliest mass shootings in the United States since 2018 were by people who were 21 or younger, a shift from earlier decades.
articles.abstract: Six of the nine deadliest mass shootings in the United States since 2018 were by people who were 21 or younger, a shift from earlier decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two young men accused of carrying out the massacres in Buffalo and Uvalde followed a familiar path: They legally bought semiautomatic rifles right after turning 18, posted images intended to display their strength and menace — and then turned those weapons on innocent people.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Why a Not-So-Hot Economy Might Be Good News
articles.snippet: As the Federal Reserve tries to rein in inflation without causing a recession, slower job creation and wage growth could be a plus.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Reserve tries to rein in inflation without causing a recession, slower job creation and wage growth could be a plus.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the economy, more is usually better.

articles.headline: How the Proud Boys Gripped the Miami-Dade Republican Party
articles.snippet: It was once Jeb Bush’s base of power. But an influx of far-right activists and the radicalization of other members brought turmoil.
articles.abstract: It was once Jeb Bush’s base of power. But an influx of far-right activists and the radicalization of other members brought turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: SPACs Were All the Rage. Now, Not So Much.
articles.snippet: For a time, SPACs were the preferred way for companies to go public. But changing market conditions and the threat of regulation are making Wall Street lose its appetite.
articles.abstract: For a time, SPACs were the preferred way for companies to go public. But changing market conditions and the threat of regulation are making Wall Street lose its appetite.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matt Higgins, a former judge on the reality TV show “Shark Tank,” is an experienced investor whose firm, RSE Ventures, helps young companies build their businesses.

articles.headline: Forget Twitter. This Musk Is Into ‘Toe Curling Yumminess.’
articles.snippet: Tosca Musk, Elon’s younger sister, is the force behind Passionflix, a streaming service dedicated to adaptations of romance novels and erotic fan fiction.
articles.abstract: Tosca Musk, Elon’s younger sister, is the force behind Passionflix, a streaming service dedicated to adaptations of romance novels and erotic fan fiction.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tosca Musk is not particularly interested in space tourism or electric car manufacturing. She is not a rabble-rouser on Twitter who is now buying Twitter. She is not rolling in money, at least not World’s Richest Person money.

articles.headline: OPEC Plus agrees to a bigger increase in oil supply. But prices keep rising.
articles.snippet: The oil producers said they would raise by 50 percent a planned production increase, after U.S. lobbying to ease price pressures.
articles.abstract: The oil producers said they would raise by 50 percent a planned production increase, after U.S. lobbying to ease price pressures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The group of oil-producing nations known as OPEC Plus agreed on Thursday to a larger increase in supply than planned for July and August.

articles.headline: ‘Not if but When’: More Mass Shootings Add to Weary Nation’s Grief
articles.snippet: The killing of four people at a medical building in Tulsa, Okla., added to a relentless toll of recent mass violence in the United States.
articles.abstract: The killing of four people at a medical building in Tulsa, Okla., added to a relentless toll of recent mass violence in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the devastating attack on an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, last week, mass shootings around the country have been relentless, coming at a pace of more than two a day.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Daniel Victor
